Ravila 19
50411 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.en: The course will provide introduction to the nanomedicine and discuss principles, opportunities and challenges in development of nanocarriers for improved cancer detection and therapy. Synthesis and characterization of nanometerials will be overviewed. Different classes of clinically relevant nanoparticles  and regulatory landscape of nanodrug development will be discussed.  Practical laboratory work on peptide guided biological nanoparticles will be carried out at the lab of cancer biology fo the University of Tartu.
description.et: Kursusel käsitletakse nanomeditsiini aluspõhimõtteid ja nanomeditsiinist lähtuvaid võimalusi parandada kasvajaliste haiguste diagnostikat ja ravi. Ravimiarendusega seotud teadlased annavad ülevaate vähktõve modelleerimisest koekultuuris ja loommudelites ning nende mudelite kasutamisest prekliinilises ravimiarenduses.

objectives.en: The course will cover principles of molecular mechnisms of carcinogenesis on cellular, tissue, and organism levesl; preclinical modeling of cancer and development of anticancer drugs;  as well as provide introduction to advanced cancer therapies.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on anda ülevaade kliiniliselt kasutatavate nanoosakeste klassidest ning rakendustest kasvajaliste haiguste diagnostikaks ja -raviks.

learning_outcomes.en: A student who has completed the curriculum:
1. Has understanding of the molecular pathways involved in oncogenesis and general principles of cancer therapy;
learning_outcomes.et: 1.     On tuttav nanomeditsiini aluspõhimõtetega ja nende rakendamisega kasvajaliste haiguste raviks.

learning_outcomes.en: 2. Can describe strategies of preclinical and clinical development of anticancer compounds;
learning_outcomes.et: 2.     On tuttav kliiniliselt relevantsete nanoosakeste klassidega ja täppisnanoteraapia põhimõtetega.
3.     Omab ettekujutust nanotoksikoloogiast ja nanoravimite prekliinilisest ja kliinilisest arendusest.

grade_preconditions.et: Osalemine viies loengus seitsmest, ühes seminaris ja kahes praktikumis

grade_evaluation.et:
Kodutöö ja ettekande positiivne sooritus.
Üliõpilane on tuttav nanomeditsiini aluspõhimõtetega ja nende rakendamisega kasvajaliste haiguste raviks; on tuttav kliiniliselt relevantsete nanoosakeste klassidega ja täppisnanoteraapia põhimõtetega ning omab ettekujutust nanotoksikoloogiast ja nanoravimite prekliinilisest ja kliinilisest arendusest.

structural_unit.address:
Ravila 19
50411 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.et:
Date: March 5
Instructor: Professor Tambet Teesalu
•	Overview of the laboratory
•	Nanotechnologies in Medicine and Healthcare: Current state, challenges, and future opportunities.
•	Multifunctionality of Nanoparticles: From diagnostics to therapeutics.
•	Preclinical Nanomedicine Research:
o	Model systems: 2D/3D in vitro models, organoids, and in vivo animal models.

Date: March 12
Instructor: Professor  Pablo Scodeller (via Zoom)
•	Overview of Nanoparticulate Systems: Definitions, classification, and applications.
•	Lipid-Based Nanoparticles: Liposomes, solid lipid nanoparticles, and nanostructured lipid carriers.
•	Polymeric Nanoparticles: Polymersomes, dendrimers, and micelles.
•	Protein-Based Nanoparticles: Virus-like particles, ferritin, and albumin-based carriers.
•	Inorganic Nanoparticles: Quantum dots, gold/silver nanoparticles, and silica nanoparticles.
•	Hybrid Nanoparticles: Combining materials for multifunctionality.

topic.et: L 3: Preparation and Characterization of Nanosystems for Medical Applications

description.et:
Date: March 19
Instructor: Professor Pablo Scodeller (via Zoom)
•	Biophysical Principles of Nanosystems: Key design considerations for nanocarriers.
•	Stability of Nanosystems: Influence of pH, ionic strength, and temperature.
•	Surface Modifications: PEGylation, targeting ligands, and stealth coatings.
•	Interaction with Biomacromolecules: Protein corona formation and its implications.
•	Characterization Techniques:
o	Size and surface charge (DLS, zeta potential).
o	Morphology (TEM, SEM).
o	Surface chemistry and ligand density (FTIR, XPS).

topic.et: L 4: Precision Nanoparticles for Targeted Therapy

description.et:
Date: March 26
Instructor: Professor Tambet Teesalu
•	Active and Passive Targeting: Enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect.
•	Mapping Vascular Heterogeneity: In vivo peptide phage display and biochemical techniques.
•	Nanoparticles for Non-Malignant Diseases: Applications in cardiovascular, inflammatory, and neurodegenerative conditions.

topic.et: L 5: Lipid Nanoparticles (LNPs) I: Fundamentals and Applications

description.et:
Date: April 2
Instructors: Kristina Põsnograjeva and Dr. Vladimirs Pilipenko
•	Introduction to LNPs: Structure, composition, and applications.
•	Lipid Selection and Composition: Cholesterol, ionizable lipids, PEGylation, and stabilizers.
•	Formulation Techniques: Microfluidics, ethanol injection, and nanoprecipitation.
•	Applications of LNPs: Vaccine development, drug delivery, and therapeutic nucleic acids.

Date: April 9
Instructor: Professor Ana Rebane
•	Overview of RNA Therapeutics: siRNA, mRNA, miRNA, saRNA, and pDNA.
•	Designing RNA Nanoparticle Systems: Key considerations for stability, protection, and delivery.
•	Nanoparticle Platforms for RNA Delivery: LNPs, polymeric nanoparticles, and hybrid systems.
•	Challenges and Opportunities: Immune response, off-target effects, and long-term safety.
•	Clinical Development Pipeline: RNA therapies for cancer, infectious diseases, and genetic disorders.

topic.et: L 7: Lipid Nanoparticles (LNPs) II: Challenges and Innovations

description.et:
Date: April 16
Instructors: Kristina Põsnograjeva and Dr. Vladimirs Pilipenko
•	Biological Barriers in LNP Delivery: Overcoming immune clearance and endosomal escape.
•	Optimization Strategies: Enhancing targeting specificity and biodistribution.
•	Emerging Innovations: Functionalized LNPs, stimuli-responsive LNPs, and personalized LNP platforms.
•	Case Studies: COVID-19 mRNA vaccines and beyond.

topic.et: L 8: Development of Nanosystems for Wound Care

description.et:
Date: April 23
Instructor: Dr. Olesja Bondarenko
•	Nanomaterials in Wound Healing: Hydrogels, nanofibers, and nanoparticle-based dressings.
•	Antimicrobial Nanoparticles: Silver nanoparticles, zinc oxide, and their mechanisms.
•	Promoting Regeneration: Growth factor delivery and stem cell recruitment.
•	Emerging Technologies: Smart wound dressings with real-time monitoring.
•	Case Studies: Clinical applications in diabetic ulcers and burn wounds.
  oral presentations, discussion (HOD) 1

topic.et: L 9: Developing naomedicines in Estonia: Vectiopep case study

description.et:
Date: April 30
Instructor: Professor Kaido Kurrikoff

topic.et: L 10: Nano-Based Strategies for Controlled Drug Delivery

description.et:
Date: May 7
Instructor: Professor Tambet Teesalu
•	Responsive Drug Release Mechanisms:
o	Thermo-responsive.
o	Enzyme-responsive.
o	pH-responsive.
•	Sustained Drug Release: Achieving long-term therapeutic effects.
•	Applications in Oncology, Infectious Diseases, and Regenerative Medicine.

Homework,  oral presentations, discussion (HOD) April -May  (Tambet Teesalu)

„Journal Club“, May 14 and 21, Tambet Teesalu
•	Each student chooses one landmark nanomedicine paper to present to the others.
•	Papers and instructions for presentations will be available 4 weeks before the seminars.
•	12 min presentation + 3 min  of discussion and questions.

„Journal Club“, May 14 and 21, Tambet Teesalu
•	Each student chooses one landmark nanomedicine paper to present to the others.
•	Papers and instructions for presentations will be available 4 weeks before the seminars.
•	12 min presentation + 3 min  of discussion and questions.
Laboratory practice 1:  Rasmus Enno, Kristina Põsnograjeva, Jorgen Holm, Luca Marchetti, Jhalak Sethi, Kaarel Kurm
Laboratory practice 2:  Rasmus Enno, Kristina Põsnograjeva, Jorgen Holm, Luca Marchetti, Jhalak Sethi, Kaarel Kurm
